entries.name: Running the Adventure
entries: This adventure is intended for the {@b Dungeon Master (DM)} and assumes familiarity with the {@b Fifth Edition} core rules. The following section introduces the tone, world context, and framework for running {@b {@i Vaelithra–Into Raijinsho}} within the {@b Malvidra Twisted World} setting.

This module emphasizes {@b exploration and survival} rather than extended combat—each encounter is deliberate, deadly, and meant to be memorable. The focus lies on the island's oppressive cold, the eerie stillness of a forgotten people, and the divine mystery lurking beneath the ice.

entries.name: Overview
entries: {@b {@i Vaelithra–Into Raijinsho}} is a high-level one-shot designed for {@b Level 7–9} characters, though it is best experienced at {@b Level 9} for full narrative and mechanical tension. It serves as both a standalone expedition and a key part of the ongoing {@b Vaelithra Saga}, where fragments of the shattered god {@b Vaeil} appear across time and space.

items: {@b Author / Universe:} Malvidra Twisted World
{@b World:} Dewanegara
{@b Primary Themes:} {@i Exploration (Frozen Island), Survival (Extreme Cold), Divine Mystery}
{@b Tone:} Harsh isolation, hidden divinity, and brief warmth in the dark
{@b Timeline:} 6th Sol'thara, Sylvryn Day, Year 35 A.S. (After Sundering)

entries.name: Adventure Summary
entries: The adventurers are drawn into the service of {@b Captain Thania Schmidt}, a hardened pirate chasing an old legend of the {@b Sacred Eye}—a brotherhood of thieves who once ruled the seas around Thundrum City. Her goal is simple: raid the long-lost treasure vault beneath {@b Raijinsho Island}, now home to the feared {@b White Dragon Harann Nemmonis}.
Yet fate weaves deeper threads.

A mysterious {@b Sea Urchin Newspaper Girl}, {@i Renata}, guides them not for gold, but for destiny. She is no mortal messenger, but a {@b Vaelithra Fragment}, a shard of the God of Time, here to preserve the sacred balance by freeing Raijinsho from Harann's grasp before divine corruption consumes it forever.
The heroes must brave a voyage through lethal cold, mistrustful pirates, and a labyrinth of ice—to find not only treasure, but the {@b Koi Vaelithra}, a sacred fragment of time itself.

entries.name: DM's Goals
entries: Running {@i Into Raijinsho} means balancing {@b environmental dread} and {@b divine awe}:
1. {@b Build isolation.} The cold is as much an enemy as the dragon.
2. {@b Pace tension.} Use exploration and crew tension to let the fear breathe.
3. {@b Deliver wonder.} The encounter with the Koi Vaelithra should feel sacred, like touching eternity.
Let your players feel both {@i fragility and purpose.}

rows: Reduce the number of Frost-Cursed minions by one per encounter. Consider making Harann's HP threshold for retreat 25% higher.
Add one additional Frost-Cursed elite or minor environmental hazard in each chapter. The voyage may feature an extra divine omen from Renata.

entries.name: Required Materials
entries: To run this adventure, you'll need the {@b Player's Handbook (PHB)}, {@b Dungeon Master's Guide (DMG)}, and {@b Monster Manual (MM)}.
Custom monsters—{@b Frost-Cursed Mariners}, {@b Frost-Cursed Soldiers}, and {@b Dragon-Kin Variants}—should be prepared beforehand or substituted with similar CR foes from the MM.

rows: Extreme Cold (p.110), creating monsters, treasure tables
Managing the cold and loot balance
White Dragon (CR 13) base, undead & humanoid templates
Reference for Harann and her minions

entries.name: Content Warning
entries: This adventure features {@b environmental survival}, {@b themes of death and decay}, and {@b divine manipulation}.
It is not a tale of radiant heroism, but of endurance, faith, and the faint warmth that refuses to die in endless frost.

entries.name: The Sundering War and Vaeil's Fractured Legacy
entries: The world of {@b Dewanegara} still bears the scars of the {@b Sundering War}—the cosmic conflict that tore heaven and earth apart. It was a war not of armies, but of {@i belief itself}, where gods and demons bled through the seams of time to seize control of the mortal world.

When the war reached its climax, {@b Vaeil}, the {@b God of Time and Keeper of the Archives}, saw the threads of reality unraveling. Neither side would relent, and both were doomed to mutual extinction. To preserve existence, Vaeil broke the laws of his own domain—rewriting history.

He shaped an outcome where the gods won... but at the cost of the world's balance. His interference was forbidden, and so, as punishment and penance, he shattered his essence into twelve divine shards known as the {@b Vaelithra}. Each fragment carried a sliver of his divine will and memory, scattered across worlds and time.
Some took the form of relics, some of spirits, and some—like the {@b Human Vaelithra, Renata}—became living avatars bound by purpose: to weave moments where fate might once again turn toward harmony.

entries.name: The Island of Raijinsho
entries: Once, {@b Raijinsho Island} was not a wasteland of frost and death, but a place of quiet devotion. Its people lived in harmony with the storms that circled their shores, worshipping the {@b Serpent God of Health and Envy}—a patron of renewal through hardship.

Their faith taught that envy, when tempered, could drive the sick to seek healing and the weak to seek strength. Shrines carved into the cliffs once shimmered with offerings of jade, coral, and carved fangs representing rebirth through struggle.

Among these denizens thrived a notorious yet noble band of pirates known as the {@b Sacred Eye}. Though branded criminals by Thundrum City's rulers, they were protectors of the seas, shielding travelers and local traders from slavers and monsters alike. The Sacred Eye built their stronghold within the caverns of Raijinsho—half sanctuary, half treasure vault.
When the {@b Sundering's aftermath} twisted magic and weather across Dewanegara, the Sacred Eye vanished, leaving their treasures buried beneath the island's waves and their oaths buried in history.

entries.name: Harann Nemmonis—The Frost Sovereign
entries: In the void of that disappearance came {@b Harann Nemmonis}, a cruel {@b Adult White Dragon} drawn by the whisper of lingering magic and the promise of dominion. She claimed Raijinsho as her eternal lair, her will manifesting as an endless, supernatural winter that choked all warmth from sea and sky.

Her cruelty is not born of madness but {@i entitlement}—she views herself as a god of the new age, the rightful successor to the Serpent whose temples she desecrated. Her breath froze the shrines, her claws tore through the vaults, and her curse bound the dead to her service.

Those who tried to reclaim the Sacred Eye's treasure—pirates, mercenaries, even knights—fell to her blizzard. Their corpses became {@b Frost-Cursed Mariners}, servants bound by her magic to guard her hoard for eternity.
Raijinsho became a graveyard of greed.

entries.name: The Koi Vaelithra—Fragment of Warm Eternity
entries: Hidden deep beneath the frozen caverns lies one of Vaeil's divine shards: the {@b Koi Vaelithra}. This fragment manifests as a silver-scaled koi spirit that swims within a magically warm subterranean pond—untouched by Harann's frost.

The Koi's power preserves a small circle of serenity, a final remnant of the Serpent God's domain. Its divine energy continually resists Harann's control, and if fully awakened, could {@i restore the island's natural balance}—but the dragon's corruption grows stronger each year.

The {@b Human Vaelithra, Renata}, foresaw this decay through the Archives of Time. To preserve the fragment and Raijinsho's sanctity, she {@i stepped backward through time itself}, appearing in the current age to orchestrate one decisive event: the removal of Harann Nemmonis.

By weaving mortal greed, divine design, and the illusion of coincidence, Renata ensures that a band of capable adventurers will board Captain Thania's ship at the right moment—unknowingly answering a god's summons hidden within a pirate's bargain.

entries.name: The Divine Threads of Purpose
entries: This is not a story of divine prophecy fulfilled, but of mortals entangled in one.
Renata's motives are not kindness—they are necessity. The Vaelithra cannot act directly without collapsing time's flow, so she sets mortals into motion, {@i sacrificing their comfort for continuity}.
Those who follow her will walk the thin edge between survival and sanctity.
Those who defy her will still play their part.
For in Vaeil's grand design, {@b fate is not a promise—it's a pattern.}

entries.name: ADVENTURE OUTLINE
entries: The adventure begins not with destiny declared, but with {@b a rumor sold for gold}—and a divine thread hiding beneath it.

{@b Captain Thania Schmidt}, a ruthless yet pragmatic pirate, seeks to reclaim the legendary treasure of the {@b Sacred Eye}, a mythic crew once said to have buried their greatest wealth beneath {@b Raijinsho Island}. Her ambitions are far from noble—she only desires the gold, gems, and spoils the dragon guards.

But this particular raid is not chance. It is the quiet design of {@b Renata}, the {@b Human Vaelithra}, who disguised herself as a humble newspaper girl to ensure the right heroes take Thania's bait. Her true purpose is divine: to restore Raijinsho to its living color, and to protect the {@b Koi Vaelithra} from being forever entombed under Harann's frost.

Unbeknownst to Thania or her crew, the voyage itself fulfills a {@b temporal ripple}—one Renata planted long ago when she traveled back through the Archives to undo the future where Raijinsho remains dead and silent.

entries.name: The Sacred Eye's Echo
entries: For centuries, the legend of the Sacred Eye persisted among pirates of {@b Thundrum City}, whispered in taverns thick with salt and deceit. The story tells of a final voyage, where the crew hid their treasure beneath the Serpent God's temple on Raijinsho.
When the island froze under Harann's dominion, countless captains sought the gold, but none returned. Their names faded into ice-bound ghosts—the first of the {@b Frost-Cursed Mariners}.

Thania's {@b first mate, Kaelen}, lost a brother in one of those doomed expeditions. It's why Thania waited—gathering information, salvaging charts, and stealing old logbooks until she was certain she knew where the dragon slept.
Now, with desperation biting harder than the cold, she has decided it's time to strike—so long as she finds others foolish or strong enough to serve as her vanguard.

entries.name: Renata's Orchestration
entries: Renata does not stumble upon the adventurers.
She finds them deliberately, standing upon the docks of {@b Thundrum Port} as the world drifts toward one of its repeating points of collapse.

Through her mortal guise, she plants curiosity, temptation, and the faint pulse of divine urgency in the hearts of the party. To her, they are not chosen {@i heroes}, but variables—souls that must move, or time itself will stagnate.
The players will see her as a quiet, strange girl clutching a bundle of newspapers. Only later will they realize her words shaped their path long before they set sail.

entries.name: Adventure Progression Overview

rows: Social interaction, roleplay, and negotiation. Introduction to Thania, Renata, and the pirate contract.
Environmental survival and interpersonal tension aboard the *Glowing Gate*. Tests the party's endurance, leadership, and trust.
Exploration and tactical combat. Crossing the frozen sea, navigating the labyrinth, and confronting Harann Nemmonis to reclaim Raijinsho.

entries: Each chapter should flow like a heartbeat: slow and heavy before a sudden, powerful surge. Allow silence to fill the gaps between action—it's in those moments the divine threads hum the loudest.

items: {@b Defeat or drive away Harann Nemmonis}, ending her dominion over Raijinsho Island.
{@b Locate and secure the Koi Vaelithra}, ensuring its divine protection.
{@b Survive the extreme cold} and maintain crew morale through the voyage.
{@b Fulfill (or betray)} the pirate contract, shaping the group's reputation across Thundrum and the seas beyond.

rows: The pirates distrust outsiders. Winning their respect can secure supplies, safety, or hidden lore.
Fragments of journals, carvings, and frozen bodies reveal hints of the Sacred Eye's final stand—and the fate of Kaelen's brother.
Renata may appear briefly in dreams, giving cryptic visions about "the silver scale beneath the endless white."
Thania's deal favors profit; the Vaelithra's path favors salvation. The players must decide which voice they follow.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: The adventure begins on the {@b docks of Thundrum Port}, where the adventurers are resting, resupplying, or searching for new work. It's {@b Sylvryn Day}, and the harbor thrums with life—hawkers shouting, sailors brawling, the clang of chains and the hiss of steamships venting on the tide.

There's no panic, no omen—just another day in a city that survives on salt and sin. Yet, for a reason none of them can name, the wind feels... expectant. The chill that brushes across their skin lingers longer than it should, as though the sea itself is holding its breath.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The docks of {@b Thundrum Port} are loud and bright beneath the late morning sun. Fishmongers haggle, gulls scream overhead, and the sharp tang of brine and ale fills the air. Amidst the crowd, a calm voice cuts through the noise—
"News from the northern seas!"

A {@b young newspaper girl} stands at the edge of the pier, her coat patched and boots scuffed. Her eyes, a pale silver, shimmer faintly as she scans the crowd. Then she looks directly at you and smiles—as if she's been waiting all along.
This quiet arrival replaces the expected chaos of Thundrum with something subtler: the feeling that fate has just turned its gaze.
Renata's presence in this perfectly ordinary day marks the moment the adventurers' story begins to unravel the stillness of time itself.

items: {@b Act I–The Hook (Roleplay):} Renata delivers the message and draws the adventurers into Thania's contract.
{@b Act II–The Voyage (Tension & Survival):} The party endures the cold, growing distrust, and the first touch of the dragon's influence.
{@b Act III–The Ice (Exploration & Combat):} The final confrontation and the discovery of the Koi Vaelithra.
{@b Act IV–The Thaw (Resolution):} The dragon's defeat lifts the curse, setting the stage for the next fragment.

entries.name: The Docks of Fate

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The docks of {@b Thundrum Port} are alive with chaos and commerce. Dockhands shout, gulls scream, and the air smells of brine, sweat, and spilled ale. A ship's bell rings in the distance as sailors haul crates of spice and contraband beneath the morning sun.

The day feels ordinary—too ordinary. Even the chill that lingers on the wind seems only the work of the season, not the warning of something greater. Yet beneath the noise, the rhythm of the harbor feels... waiting.
This chapter introduces the players to {@b Renata} (the Human Vaelithra) and {@b Captain Thania Schmidt}, setting the hook for their voyage to Raijinsho.

entries.name: A Subtle Intrusion
entries: As the players navigate the port—whether restocking, seeking work, or boasting of past victories—one voice cuts through the din.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
"News from the northern seas!"

The cry is clear, carried not by desperation but precision. A small {@b newspaper girl} stands at the end of the pier, a stack of papers under one arm. Her clothes are plain, her boots worn from salt, yet her silver-gray eyes gleam like still water catching sunlight.
She studies your group for only a moment before approaching with unnerving certainty.

entries.name: The Unlikely Messenger
entries: Renata wastes no time. Her tone is polite but focused, as though reciting something that has already happened.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
"Captain Thania Schmidt of the {@i Glowing Gate} seeks a capable crew for a northern expedition—{@i Raijinsho Island.}
She pays in gold and allows half share of any {@i magic relics} found on-site. Departure: next high tide."
She pauses, her gaze sharpening. "She's not hiring dreamers. You look... real enough."

entries.name: DM Information

items: {@b Identity:} Renata is the {@b Human Vaelithra}, a living shard of Vaeil, manifesting in mortal guise.
{@b Stat Base:} {@i Scout} (MM p. 349), modified with {@b Persuasion +5}, {@b Insight +4}, and the ability to cast {@i Guidance} once per short rest.
{@b Goal:} Ensure the party accepts Thania's contract and boards before the next tide.
{@b Atmosphere Cue:} The nearby gulls quiet as she speaks. The air feels still, as if the sea is holding its breath.

entries: A successful {@b Insight (DC 18)} reveals something timeless behind her calm demeanor—an echo of memory far older than her years. Reward recognition with {@b Inspiration}.

entries.name: A Moment to Prepare (Act 0)
entries: Renata points toward a ship moored a few piers away—a battered caravel with patched sails and a painted name barely legible: {@i The Glowing Gate.}
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
"She's waiting. If you're interested, tell her Renata sent you."
The girl's silver eyes linger for a heartbeat longer, then she slips into the crowd. One blink—and she's gone, as if she'd never been there.

Players may use this moment to roleplay freely—decide whether to trust the offer, question locals, or make lore checks to recall Raijinsho's history or the Sacred Eye pirates (use your original DC table here).
If they ask around, common folk dismiss the rumor:
"Raijinsho? Nobody sails there now. Ice took it years ago."
"Captain Schmidt? She's mad—but she pays well if you live long enough to collect."
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The {@i Glowing Gate} lists lazily against the pier, her hull patched and her figurehead weathered beyond recognition. A short, powerfully built woman waits at the gangplank—sun-browned, scarred, and unimpressed.
"You the ones Renata sent?" she says without greeting. "Good. Saves me shouting."

entries.name: DM Information
entries: {@b Captain Thania Schmidt} uses {@i Bandit Captain} stats with {@b Wisdom (Insight) +4}.
She's pragmatic, mercenary-minded, and deeply superstitious, though she hides it under cynicism.
She doesn't trust magic, and sees the adventurers as expendable muscle.

items: "It's simple. You help me clear the island of that overgrown lizard and her frost-ridden dead, we split the spoils."
"You take half the {@i magic stuff}—scrolls, crystals, whatever nonsense you fancy. I take coin, gems, and trade goods."
"You want gold? Prove you'll live to spend it."
{@b Persuasion DC 17:} Thania grudgingly adds a {@b 5,000 gp guaranteed payout} upon return.
{@b Failure:} She grows cold and dismissive, but Renata's later intervention (see below) ensures the voyage still proceeds.

entries.name: Vaelithra Intervention (Fail-Safe)
entries: If negotiations collapse or the party refuses:
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
The world freezes—not metaphorically, but truly. The breeze stops mid-whisper, gulls hang suspended in the air, and even the surf halts in mid-splash.
Renata stands again at the dock's edge, voice calm but undeniable:
"Five thousand gold upon return. That will satisfy you both."
Time resumes, leaving only the faint scent of ozone. Thania blinks, shudders, and nods as though it were her own idea.
Grant {@b Advantage} on the next {@b Persuasion} roll; Thania reluctantly agrees.

entries.name: Departure Timeline
entries: Once the deal is struck:
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
"Good," Thania says curtly. "We sail before the tide turns. Pack what you need, say your prayers, and don't be late. Raijinsho won't wait for anyone."
The ship prepares swiftly. Dockhands load the last crates, Kaelen shouts orders from the rigging, and the city noise fades beneath the growing roar of the sea.
When the {@i Glowing Gate} finally casts off, the light of {@b Sylvryn Day} glints across the waves like fractured glass—bright, beautiful, and fleeting.

data.name: Chapter 2 - The Journey and The Cold

entries.name: Setting Sail

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The {@b Glowing Gate} groans away from {@b Thundrum Port}, its weathered hull cutting into the turbulent waves. The noise of the city fades fast, replaced by the creak of timber and the snap of patched sails. The air, though still early in the day, has a brittle, chilling edge—the first, subtle touch of the dragon's dominion. {@b Captain Thania Schmidt} gives you a single, grim nod. "Forty-eight hours to Raijinsho," she says, her voice hard. "If the cold doesn't kill you, my crew might."
The voyage to {@b Raijinsho Island} is a two-day (48-hour) test of endurance. This chapter is designed to:
1.  {@b Drain Resources:} Challenge the party's ability to stay warm and alert.
2.  {@b Build Tension:} Establish the mistrust between the adventurers and the pirate crew.
3.  {@b Foreshadow the Dragon:} Introduce the unnatural cold and Harann's icy minions.

entries.name: Environmental Rules: The Chill of Nemmonis
entries: As the ship nears the {@b Adult White Dragon's (Harann Nemmonis')} domain, the cold is intensified by her ancient, corrupt magic.
The environment progresses in danger over the 48-hour period. Use or adapt the following:

rows: A relentless wind from the north.
Creatures without **cold weather gear** suffer **Disadvantage** on **Dexterity (Acrobatics)** and **Wisdom (Perception)** checks.
Dense, chilling mist. Breath fogs instantly.
Each hour, a creature not protected must make a **DC 10 Constitution saving throw** or gain one level of **Exhaustion**.
Sleet, frost, and near-freezing sea spray.
The **Constitution saving throw DC rises to 12**. Failure results in gaining one level of **Exhaustion** AND taking **2d6 Cold damage**.

entries: Encourage players to ration firewood, spell slots, and food. Warmth becomes a crucial resource.

entries.name: Voyage Random Encounter and Omen Table
entries: Roll 1d6 every 6–8 hours, or when the party rests, to inject tension and flavor.

rows: Visibility drops to 15 feet. Figures seem to move within the mist, but they vanish when approached. A creature making a successful **Wisdom (Perception) DC 14** check sees a faint, stylized **Koi symbol** briefly flicker in the gloom.

A sudden, unnatural rime flowers across metal and cloth. Anyone using a metallic weapon or wearing heavy armor must scrape the frost off (costing 10 minutes) or suffer **Disadvantage** on their next **Attack Roll** due to brittle ice.

**Kaelen**, the First Mate, violently accuses a deckhand of hearing the "ice whisper." A successful **Charisma (Persuasion) DC 15** check can calm the crew; failure leads to lasting **Distrust** from the pirates towards the party.

During a long rest, one PC has a vivid dream of a **silver-scaled Koi** swimming through black ice toward a source of deep, subterranean warmth. The PC wakes with a sense of quiet purpose and gains **Advantage** on their next saving throw against cold.

The *Glowing Gate* passes the remains of a doomed expedition. An active search (**Intelligence (Investigation) DC 14**) of the wreckage uncovers frozen corpses branded with the **Sacred Eye** symbol, confirming the fate of past raiders and foreshadowing the Frost-Cursed.

A sudden bolt of solid ice, a **frozen lightning** strike, crashes into the sea, rocking the ship and showering the deck with shards. All on deck must succeed on a **DC 13 Dexterity saving throw** or take **1d6 piercing damage**.

entries.name: Roleplay Thread: Kaelen's Grudge
entries: During the second day, when the cold has fully set in, {@b Kaelen} (Bandit stats) will approach the party. Her tension comes from a deep, personal source—the death of her brother.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

Kaelen leans on the frozen railing, her breath smoking in the wind. She doesn't look at you. "My brother went after that island five years ago. He thought the {@b Sacred Eye's} gold was waiting for him. Harann sent back his body, frozen solid to a piece of driftwood."
Her jaw tightens. "So forgive me if I don't cheer for you high-and-mighty heroes chasing ghosts and magic. I hope you're better fighters than he was, or we'll all end up Frost-Cursed."

{@b Insight DC 13} reveals that her contempt is a mask for her grief and fear; she is intensely loyal to Captain Thania. A successful {@b Charisma (Persuasion) DC 15} check, or a genuinely empathetic response, will soften her tone.

{@b Success:} Kaelen grudgingly respects the party's mettle. She shares a final, critical piece of lore: {@b "The Dragon-Kin Soldiers carry horns. They use them to shift the ice and block tunnels. If you hear the horn, change your plan."}
{@b Failure:} Kaelen remains suspicious and distrustful, making it harder to secure supplies or help from the pirate crew later on.

entries.name: A Silence on the Waves

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}
The second night bleeds into gray morning. The fog thickens until the horizon vanishes, and the {@i Glowing Gate} feels like it's sailing through milk. The air grows so still that even the sails sag.
Then, faintly, the sound of bells—soft, rhythmic, impossibly close—rings through the mist.
A {@b DC 15 Perception check} reveals ghostly shapes drifting on the water ahead: another ship, iced over and partially submerged.
If approached, the deck bears the sigil of the {@b Sacred Eye} carved into frozen wood.

entries.name: Encounter: *The Frost-Cursed Mariners*
entries: {@b Setup:}

Four to six undead sailors (use {@i Wight} or {@i Ghoul} stats, tinted by frost). They are remnants of Thania's predecessors—pirates who sought the Sacred Eye treasure decades ago. Their eyes glow faint blue, their flesh stiff as glass.
{@b Read-Aloud Text (Combat Intro):}
The shapes on the deck move—slow, deliberate. Ice cracks as they turn toward you.
The first raises its head. Frost falls from its beard in sheets.
"{@i You came for gold...}" it rasps. "{@i So did we.}"

items: {@b Environment:} Slippery frozen deck (Dex Save DC 12 or fall prone if dashing).
{@b Tactics:} They drag intruders into the freezing water (Grapple DC 13 → Con Save DC 14 or take 2d6 cold dmg each turn).
{@b Twist:} On the third round, Kaelen recognizes one of them—her brother.

entries.name: Kaelen's Moment
entries: If Kaelen is present, she freezes mid-fight.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}
Her sword lowers. Her lips part but no sound comes out.
"...Brother?"
The creature twitches, then lunges—not out of hate, but reflex. Its eyes flicker with a moment of pain before the frost claims it again.
{@b Player Choice Moment:}

items: A {@b Persuasion DC 17} or {@b Religion DC 15} can help Kaelen strike the final blow with peace.
Failure causes her to hesitate, leaving her open to attack (auto-hit for 2d6 cold).

entries: When the undead falls, the ice around it melts slightly, revealing a {@b rusted locket} engraved with the Serpent symbol—foreshadowing the Koi Vaelithra's power.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: The {@i Glowing Gate} drifts in silence. The fog seems heavier after the fight, pressing close like a held breath.
Thania orders the remains burned with black powder, her voice flat.
Kaelen says nothing, only stares at the melting ice where her brother fell.
If the players comfort her or help with the ritual, she will later defend them fiercely against Thania's doubts—a trust that can change the tone of Chapter 3 entirely.

items: {@b 500 XP each} (for mercy, combat, or giving peace).
The {@b Locket of the Serpent Eye}:
Once per long rest, as a bonus action, the bearer may gain {@b Resistance to Cold Damage for 1 minute}.
When used, it glows faintly—a pulse of the Vaelithra's warmth.

entries.name: Transition: The Ice Horizon

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}

Hours later, the mist parts just enough to reveal the impossible—a stretch of solid ice spanning the ocean ahead. Beyond it, jagged peaks pierce the clouds. Lightning flickers through them in total silence.
"Raijinsho," Thania murmurs, gripping the rail.
The ship slows, hull grinding against the first rim of frost.
The crew begins preparations to disembark, their breath already turning to mist.
Renata appears on deck for the first time since departure, her silver eyes faintly glowing in the dim light.
Without a word, she gazes toward the island, as though staring into her own reflection.

data.name: Chapter 3 - Into The Labyrinth of Ice
entries: This final chapter features the exploration of {@b Raijinsho Island}, the confrontation with {@b Harann Nemmonis}, and the discovery of the {@b Koi Vaelithra}.

entries.name: Phase 1: The Frozen Approach
entries: The ship is forced to halt where the water becomes a vast, jagged expanse of {@b frozen sea}.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The sea has become a nightmare. The water is no longer fluid, but a sheet of ancient, jagged ice that stretches for a mile, a vast, silent plain of danger. {@b Captain Thania} hands you a coil of rope and a grim look. "This is where we part ways, mercenaries. Good luck. We'll be waiting for your signal."

entries.name: The Treacherous Sea (Skill Challenge)
entries: The half-mile journey across the frozen sea maintains the {@b Extreme Cold} rules (DC 12 Con save/hour, 2d6 Cold damage on failure). To safely and quickly reach the island shore, the party must collectively achieve {@b 6 successes} before accumulating 3 failures.

rows: To find stable paths and navigate by the shifting winds.
To climb over high, slippery ice ridges and secure ropes.
To predict thin ice or weak points in the sea.
To traverse slick, uneven patches without falling.

entries: {@b Consequence of 3 Failures:} The party falls into a hidden crevasse or triggers a patch of thin ice. They take {@b 2d6 bludgeoning damage} from the fall and must spend one round stabilizing and climbing out (using a DC 13 Athletics check).

entries.name: Ambush: The Corrupted Patrol
entries: Midway across the ice, the party is attacked.

items: {@b Enemies:} {@b Three Frost-Cursed Mariner} and {@b One Frost-Cursed Captain}.

{@b Dragon's Foreshadowing:} During the combat, a shadow should pass briefly overhead—a fleeting sign that {@b Harann Nemmonis} is aware of the intruders, though she is too arrogant to intervene personally at this distance.

entries.name: Frozen Corpse Loot (Reinforce Survival)
entries: Allow players to search one or two frozen corpses they pass along the way (use the loot table from the {@i Story Outline.md} file). The most useful find would be the {@i *Scroll of }Protection from Energy{@b * (Cold only) or the }Potent Antifreeze** to help with the Extreme Cold saves.

entries.name: The Snow-Covered Shore
entries: The party reaches a wide beach buried under deep snow, which counts as {@b difficult terrain}. Guarding the central entrance to the {@b Cave Labyrinth} are the dragon's organized forces.

items: {@b Enemies:} {@b Two Frost-Cursed Kobold} and {@b Two Frost-Cursed Soldier} (use {@i Ogre} or {@i Berserker} stats with cold resistance).
{@b Tactics:} The soldiers utilize {@b Hit-and-Run} tactics, harassing the party and retreating into the caves if severely threatened, ready to ambush again inside.

entries.name: Phase 2: The Cave Labyrinth
entries: The party has successfully crossed the {@b Treacherous Sea} and navigated the initial snow-covered shore. They stand at the mouth of the ice-cave labyrinth.

entries.name: Encounter 1: The Serpent's Heart Lock (Puzzle/Bypass)
entries: This encounter happens immediately upon entering the cave.
The first tunnel segment is a short, slick path leading to a choice: an immediate, narrow path to the right, or the main, wide tunnel straight ahead.

entries.name: The Koi Vaelithra Lock (The Right Path)

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The narrow tunnel to your right terminates quickly at a solid door of {@b obsidian and bronze}, unlike the ice and rock everywhere else. Carved into its surface is an ancient {@b coiled serpent}, the symbol of the {@b Serpent God of Health and Envy}. There are no handles, only shallow indentations on the serpent's scales, and the air here is faintly, unnaturally warm. This path is clearly sealed and untouched by the dragon's presence.

items: {@b The Problem:} This door leads to the {@b trap-free way} to the {@b Koi Vaelithra} in the {@b Warm Pond}, but it is sealed by the ancient denizen's {@b Geothermal Lock}.
{@b The Key:} The puzzle requires diverting the cave's natural geothermal energy.
{@b Solution (DC 15 Intelligence Checks):}
A successful {@b DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation)} check reveals three specific scales on the carving that act as pressure points, and a sequence of lights/glyph patterns around the serpent's eyes.
A successful {@b DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana)} check determines the correct {@b lever sequence} needed to divert the geothermal energy from a hidden source, triggering the door.

{@b Success:} The bronze door {@i hisses} open, revealing a short, clear, {@b trap-free tunnel} leading directly to the {@b Warm Pond} where the {@b Koi Vaelithra} waits. {@i (Note: Players should be encouraged to complete the main objective first, but this is a clear-cut victory path if they choose it.)}
{@b Failure:} A failed check results in a temporary jet of harmless steam. The party must wait {@b ten minutes} before attempting the check again.

entries.name: Encounter 2: The Pirate's Trap (The Labyrinthine Path)
entries: The party continues down the main, wider tunnel straight ahead, which appears to be the most heavily used path.

entries.name: The Frozen Treasure Repository (Wide Area / Hexagonal Room)

entries: {@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The main passage widens here, and a tunnel to the left leads into a {@b hexagonal chamber}. This space was clearly once a storage room for the {@b Sacred Eye} pirates. The walls are lined with empty, broken weapon racks and scattered debris, all covered in a thick layer of frost. In the center, a huge, black {@b ship's chest} is completely encased in a shimmering dome of ancient, {@b magically-reinforced ice}.

items: {@b Risk/Reward:} The {@b Frozen Chest} inside contains the {@b small hoard of treasures} (500 gp and two {@i Potions of Greater Healing}).

{@b The Trap Trigger:} The hexagonal room is a tripwire. {@b Harann's minions} are not stupid; they know raiders always go for the loot first. As soon as the party begins to {@i attempt to free the chest} (takes 10 minutes of effort) or enters the {@b tunnel directly in front of the hexagonal room}, the ambush is sprung.

entries.name: The Dragon-Kin Ambush (Tunnel Beyond the Hexagonal Room)
entries: This combat encounter should occur in the {@b tunnel area in front of the hexagonal room} (or {@i after} it, as you described). This makes retreat difficult and focuses the fight in a choke point.

items: {@b Enemies:} {@b Two Frost-Cursed Kobold} (to harass/distract), {@b One Frost-Cursed Ogre}, and {@b One Frost-Cursed Chieftain}.
{@b Tactics:} The Chieftain orders the Ogre to hold the tunnel entrance while the Kobolds use ranged attacks or try to flank. The Chieftain focuses on using the environment.

{@b The Hazard:} The Dragon-Kin know this tunnel is rigged. The Chieftain can use a {@b Minor Lair Action} (once per round, on its initiative count) to trigger a partial {@b ceiling collapse} of ice (DC 14 Dexterity Save or take 3d6 bludgeoning damage and be restrained by ice shards).

{@b Loot & Lore:} The defeated {@i Frost-Cursed Chieftain} drops the {@b Dragon-Kin Warhorn}. The horn is cracked, but a successful {@b DC 15 Charisma (Performance)} check allows it to be used once to cause a {@b minor cave-in} or to scare off minor minions, confirming Kaelen's warning.

entries.name: Phase 3: The Climax
entries: After defeating the ambush and passing through the tunnels, the path leads directly up to the final area.

entries.name: The Lair Entrance
entries: This final segment is the last stretch of the main tunnel leading up to the large circular chamber. The {@b Extreme Cold} rules should be at their most punishing here.

entries.name: The Final Confrontation: Harann Nemmonis
entries: The party enters the large, circular top chamber—the main lair of {@b Harann Nemmonis} (Adult White Dragon, CR 13). The confrontation proceeds as planned.

entries.name: Phase 4: The True Objective (The Koi Vaelithra)
entries: After the dragon is defeated or fled, the party can now safely use the {@b Geothermal Lock} and access the secret path.

items: {@b The Warm Pool:} The door from the first chamber leads to the warm, geothermally fed chamber.

{@b The Silver Scale:} The {@b Koi Vaelithra} floats in the water, leaving behind the {@b Silver Scale} (the fragment) for the players, granting {@b Resistance to Cold Damage} for 24 hours (the divine boon).

entries: This revised flow honors the specificity of your map, ensuring a smooth and logical progression through the lair. Let me know if you would like me to detail the {@b Epilogue} next!

items: {@b Boon:} The Koi emits a subtle, powerful energy. Any character who touches the water or the {@b Silver Scale} (see below) gains {@b Resistance to Cold Damage} for the next 24 hours.
{@b The Silver Scale:} The party finds a single {@b Silver Scale} left on the edge of the pool. This is the {@b Koi Vaelithra} fragment itself.

{@b DM Fail-Safe (If TPK is imminent):} If the party is wiped out or in dire need of help during the fight with Harann, the {@b Koi Vaelithra} freezes time. It appears before the players, restoring their resources to a {@b Long Rest} state while their enemies remain frozen. The Koi then whispers its cryptic message about the next fragment and leaves the {@b Silver Scale} as a sign before time resumes. This maintains narrative continuity despite a near-defeat.

entries.name: The Thaw and The Treasure
entries: The moment {@b Harann Nemmonis} is defeated, the ancient, corrupt magic she used to enforce the perpetual winter shatters.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

As the dragon's dark influence vanishes, the entire island seems to take a collective sigh. The air warms perceptibly, and the low, constant moan of the wind dies away. The {@i Glowing Gate} is freed from its icy cage. {@b Captain Thania} waves you over, the promise of coin gleaming in her eyes.
{@b Resolution:}

items: {@b The Payout:} Captain Thania Schmidt keeps her word. The party receives the {@b 5,000 gp guaranteed payout}. Any {@b Magic Items} the party recovered (including the {@b Silver Scale} of the Koi Vaelithra) are their personal spoils.

entries.name: The Guiding Fragment's Final Word (The Critical Interaction)
entries: The scene is set for a brief, final conversation. {@b Renata} finds the party {@i before} they board the ship, away from the pirates.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

You are walking back to the shore when the urchin girl, {@b Renata}, steps out from behind a newly thawed stack of cargo. Her clothes are ragged, but her eyes—those unnervingly silver eyes—shine with a deep, powerful relief you've never seen on a child. She offers a small, knowing smile, clutching her worn leather notebook.
{@b Renata:} "You have the shard now, yes? Good. You must hold on to it. Not for the gold, but for the life it can bring back to this world. That makes it... {@b Two of Twe—}"
She cuts off instantly, a flicker of panic crossing her face before she forces a quick, sharp laugh that doesn't quite reach her eyes.
{@b Renata:} "—I mean, {@b Two of Eleven}. Forgive me. Sometimes I lose count."
An unsettling stillness follows the correction. The players have a chance to act here.

entries.name: Player Interaction: Pressing the Guide
entries: Any character who makes a {@b DC 16 Insight check} realizes the panic was genuine and that the number {@b Twelve} was the truth, but the second number, {@b Eleven}, was a conscious, protective lie.
If the players choose to confront her, they can use their social skills:

rows: **Success:** She briefly lowers her guard. "They made me forget, but they can't make me unknow. There are **twelve** pieces. And I am **one** of them. Tell no one." She then delivers the hint (see below) and disappears.

**Success:** She flinches but stands her ground. "I am only a messenger, and I am telling you only what you *need* to know." She then delivers the hint (see below) and is immediately gone, fleeing in distress.
She maintains her mask. "It's just a game I play! I told you, I lose count." She quickly delivers the hint and fades into the breeze before they can press her again.

entries: Regardless of the outcome, she concludes with the hook for the next adventure:

{@b Renata:} "The next fragment is not ice and cold. Look for the {@b Mask of the Harlequin}. It is worn by a Warlock's phantom, hidden inside the {@b Violet Carnival's Demiplane}—a place of false mirrors and fleeting joy."

She gives a final, silent nod and fades into the crisp ocean breeze, leaving the party with more gold, a piece of a shattered god, and the shocking realization that their innocent guide is, herself, one of the divine fragments. The sails of the {@i Glowing Gate} rise, and the journey continues.

data.name: Introduction
entries: This one-shot is part of a larger narrative within the Malvidra Twisted World universe. It takes place in the final moments of Umbralos, the Month of Lengthening Shadows, and the beginning of Aetheros, the Month of Embers and Remembrance. The corruption of the Silver Light temple has plunged the city into chaos, a reflection of the troubled times.

entries.name: Running This Adventure
entries: The Ruin of Silver Light is a one-shot adventure for characters of 3rd level. It draws them into the heart of Dewanginokori, a city once blessed by divine favor and now tainted by corruption.

The story begins simply—with strangers forced together by a storm in the Boar Smile Tavern on the night of Vael'thra, the first day of the month. Soon, they discover whispers of disappearances, false blessings, and a holy order turned sinister.
The adventurers will:

items: Explore the uneasy city of Dewanginokori on Aethelos, Day 1.
Uncover the truth behind the Silver Light cult and its High Priest.
Descend into the ruins of the Silver Light temple.
Confront the cult's monstrous patron's pet, twisted by abyssal power.

entries: The climax brings them face-to-face with a fragment of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s will—the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}—and briefly with the abyssal master behind the corruption. Though the adventurers cannot fight this Archdemon, {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}, they witness how fragile time itself can be when gods and demons pull at its threads.

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: For centuries, the Silver Light order served as acolytes of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}, God of Time and Keeper of the Archive. In the city of Dewanginokori, they were beloved for their blessings—prayers over crops, safe births, successful trade, and guidance in life's trials.

Recently, however, a group of Drow elves arrived claiming devotion to {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}. In truth, they were secret worshipers of {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW} and sacrifice. Slowly, they wormed their way into the Silver Light, twisting its rituals and climbing its ranks. By the dark month of Umbralos, when the shadows lengthen, one of them was raised to High Priest. The order's blessings became bargains. Those who sought help were promised deliverance—then lured into the old temple of the Silver Light, now a ruin. There, the faithful were sacrificed to feed a horrific abyssal creature, the Archdemon's Pet, {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}.

Unseen, a fragment of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s sundered soul walks the city as a beggar woman. This {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra} cannot act directly but watches for mortals brave enough to intervene. When the adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori during a torrential storm, on Aetheros, Day 1, fate gathers them together at the Boar Smile Tavern—their meeting place and the start of their journey into the shadows of the Silver Light.

entries.name: Adventure Outline
entries: This one-shot has three main chapters and one epilogue. Each brings the adventurers deeper into the corruption of the Silver Light:

items: {@b Chapter 1 - Boar Smile Tavern}: The adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori on the stormy evening of Aetheros, Day 1. With the tavern full, they are forced together at the bar itself, strangers sharing space. They soon hear rumors: families whispering about loved ones gone missing, blessings from the Silver Light turning hollow, and a beggar woman muttering of "light turned black." This chapter bonds the party and sets the hook to investigate the Silver Light's fall.

{@b Chapter 2 - The Silver Forest}: Following clues leads the adventurers into the Silver Forest, the sacred woods once tended by the Silver Light. Once bright with moonlit leaves and glimmering streams, it is now scarred—its wildlife restless, shadows moving where they shouldn't. Here, the adventurers face skirmishes with corrupted acolytes and glimpse signs of a greater darkness. They may meet the beggar woman again, who hints at the truth: "Not all who bless serve the Keeper of Time." The adventure continues on the same or next day

{@b Chapter 3 - The Ruin of Silver Light}: The adventurers reach the ruined temple of the Silver Light. Here they discover the cult's High Priest and their terrible secret: supplicants lured to sacrifice, their lifeblood feeding the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet. This becomes the adventure's climactic battle. If victorious, the adventurers free the captives and break the cult's hold—but their victory awakens something far worse.

{@b Epilogue - The Abyss Unveiled}: As the High Priest falls and {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS} is slain, the temple trembles. A rift tears open, and the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW} manifests in his true abyssal form—Gargantuan, overwhelming, a being no mortal could stand against. Just as despair takes hold, the sky shatters into blinding light. Time cracks. Reality folds back.

entries: The adventurers find themselves once more at the Boar Smile Tavern, the storm still raging outside, as if no time has passed. The date is Aetheros, Day 1 once again—but now the Silver Light is whole again, their order loyal to {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW} once more. Only the beggar woman's gaze lingers, knowing the truth: history was rewritten by the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}.

data.name: Chapter 1: The Boar Smile Tavern
entries: The adventure begins as the adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori under a torrential storm. Seeking warmth and shelter, they enter the Boar Smile Tavern, a bustling establishment packed full of travelers, locals, and laborers all waiting out the weather. With no empty tables left, the characters are forced to sit side by side at the bar, strangers drawn together by chance—or perhaps fate.
It's Year 1 After Sundering, on the 1st of Aetheros, the village of Dewanginokori was silent as expected

The rain pours heavily outside as thunder rattles the windows of the Boar Smile Tavern. Every table is full, leaving you no choice but to share one with strangers. The warmth of the hearth can't quite chase away the chill in the air, nor the uneasy whispers of the locals.

A group of Silver Light acolytes sit near the bar, their silver-embroidered robes darkened with damp. Once revered as the city's blessing-givers, now they mutter among themselves, avoiding the gaze of common folk. A farmer leans in to whisper:
"They don't bless the crops anymore. Those who beg their help vanish into the forest... and never come back."

entries.name: Roleplaying the Scene
entries: Encourage the players to introduce their characters: their weariness from travel, their reasons for being in Dewanginokori, and their reactions to being squeezed together. While they do, snippets of hushed conversation drift from the other customers. These whispers are the first hints that something is deeply wrong in the city.

entries.name: The Bartender
entries: The bartender on duty was an Elf named {@creature Demolias Nogard|MTW-VS}. With slightly disheveled blond hair and a pair of friendly green eyes, he greeted every newcomer with a warm smile. His build was unassuming, but his attire suggested a readiness for action: a white shirt and black vest paired with brown pants rolled up at the ankles. Your eye might be drawn to the sheathed shortsword on his back, a clear sign that he was more than just a man pouring drinks.

entries.caption: Menu List
rows: Bulette broth with chopped carrots served with a sliver of cow cheese
Brown bear broth with diced snap peas served with a wheat roll
Poached pufferfish served with raw snap peas and beets and a slice of cheddar cheese
Seared striped bass served with grilled snow peas and a slab of applewood cheese
Deboned kingfish sauteed in a salty cashew sauce served with a wedge of wheat bread
Boiled rock bass bisque with marinated turnips and pumpkin

entries.name: The Server
entries: The only server on duty was a woman with a commanding presence. Her name was {@creature Diane Serpent|MTW-VS}. She was notably tall with a strong, athletic build, and her brown hair was braided into two thick pigtails that swung slightly as she shifted her weight. Her uniform consisted of a tough, sleeveless gambeson over a loose-fitting tunic, and practical boots. The centerpiece of her gear, however, was a large, two-handed hammer that leaned against the wall next to her. She didn't seem to be in a rush, a silent guardian of the peace, ready to spring into action if needed.

entries.name: Rumors of the Silver Light
entries: As your party settles into town, you can hear whispers about the local temple, the Silver Light. If you listen closely, or ask around, you might uncover some unsettling truths.

entries.name: A Missing Boy
entries: You can try to catch the eye of a nervous-looking villager or simply listen in on a hushed conversation at the tavern.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 12} {@skill Perception} or {@skill Insight} check.

{@b Success}: You overhear a man talking to a friend, his voice filled with worry. 'My son, Thomas, went into the Silver Forest days ago. They told me the Silver Light would watch over him, but he hasn't come back. I fear... I fear he's gone.'

{@b Failure}: You only catch bits and pieces of the conversation. You hear the words 'missing' and 'Silver Forest', but you can't piece together the full story. The man's distress is clear, but the details are a blur.

entries.name: A Broken Worker
entries: A local woodcutter, his clothes tattered and face pale, stumbles into the tavern, shaking and unable to speak. His eyes dart around the room in a panicked daze.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 14} {@skill Insight} or {@skill Investigation} check to try and figure out what happened to him.

{@b Success}: You manage to get his attention and, with some gentle prompting, you learn he witnessed something terrible in the woods. He doesn't say what, but a single, terrifying word escapes his lips: 'They... changed.' He then collapses, exhausted.
{@b Failure}: The man is too traumatized to respond. All you can discern is a deep, paralyzing fear. He stares blankly at the wall, unable to communicate his experience.

entries.name: A False Blessing
entries: You hear whispers about a woman who rarely leaves her home anymore. It's said she had dealings with the Silver Light, but her story is a sad one. Finding her and convincing her to talk won't be easy.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 15} {@skill Persuasion} or {@skill Intimidation} check to get her to open up.

{@b Success}: The woman, her eyes red from crying, tells you a sorrowful tale. Her brother was sick, and the Silver Light promised a cure if he came into their care. He vanished soon after, and she hasn't seen him since. She whispers, 'It wasn't a blessing. It was a lie.'
{@b Failure}: She becomes frightened and pulls away, refusing to speak of her brother. Her distress is obvious, but you can't get her to reveal why she's so afraid.

entries: These rumors paint a picture of unease and lost faith, setting suspicion on the Silver Light.

entries.name: A Call for Help
entries: The rain continues to fall in a heavy curtain outside, a steady drumming on the tavern roof. The world inside is warm and filled with the low murmur of conversation and the clinking of mugs.

Suddenly, the heavy oak door bursts open, and a gust of cold, wet air rushes in, along with a man drenched to the bone. His eyes are wide with panic and his face is streaked with rain and tears. The sound of his desperate scramble into the room, followed by his raw scream, is what shatters the quiet, forcing every conversation to an abrupt halt.
'Please!' he cries, his voice thick with terror. 'My sister—Elara! They took her!'

He clutches his chest before forcing himself to stand tall. 'They wore long gray robes, and they dragged her into the Silver Forest toward the old temple! My name is Gareth Blackwood, and I'll give you everything I have—my family's entire inheritance! Just please, bring my sister Elara Blackwood home!'

His desperate plea echoes through the sudden silence of the tavern. Every eye in the room—from the gruff dwarven merchant to the wary-looking barmaid—turns toward the man, and then to you. The weight of his hope and fear rests squarely on your shoulders.

entries.name: Into the Storm

entries: The tension from Gareth's plea dissipates as he leads you out of the tavern and into the unforgiving storm. The town's meager lights disappear behind you as you approach the dark, foreboding edge of the Silver Forest.
Here, at the treeline, Gareth stops. He turns to you, his face pale and eyes wide with terror, even more so than before.

'I can't... I can't go in there,' he stammers, pointing a shaking hand into the shadowy trees. 'I... I can't lose her again. But please, adventurers, I beg of you. Don't let them take her light forever.'
With that, he turns and flees back toward the safety of the town, leaving you alone at the mouth of the dark forest.

As the party enters the woods, two robed figures rise from the shadows of the tavern and begin to follow from a distance. These are members of the corrupted Silver Light, sent to monitor or eliminate anyone who interferes with their plans. They should remain unseen for now.

A beggar woman, huddled outside the tavern, watches the adventurers leave. This is {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, a fragment of the god Vaeil. She is observing the party's first steps on their journey, but she will not interfere. Her presence is a subtle hint of a larger, divine conflict.

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: This chapter shifts the adventure's tone entirely, moving from the safety of the tavern to the hostile tension of the woods. The Silver Forest is the players' first real taste of the corruption they are investigating, a place of twisted beauty that conceals a very real menace. This serves as a vital combat trial, meant to test your party's cohesion and combat strategy.

Encourage your players to explore the unsettling signs of corruption in the forest before the ambush. These clues are designed to build dread and foreshadow that something ancient and unnatural—the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet—lingers deeper within.

entries.name: Entering the Forest
entries: As the adventurers step beneath the forest canopy, they are met by an eerie, sudden stillness. The air grows heavy, muffling their footsteps and the patter of the rain, as if they've walked into a vacuum. The ancient trees and stones here are scarred with deep, jagged gashes, as though claws or blades have carved at the land itself. Strange silver motes drift through the branches, shimmering faintly before dissolving into nothingness when touched. Every now and then, a faint whisper—like a distorted prayer—echoes through the silence, carried on a non-existent breeze.

(Optional: A successful {@dc 15} {@skill Survival} or {@skill Arcana} check reveals that these marks are not random, but part of a sinister ritual, a deliberate defiling of the forest's natural life.)

entries.name: The Ambush at the Halfway Point
entries: Just as the party nears the halfway point to the temple ruins, five figures melt from the shadows of the forest. They block the path ahead, their silver robes and gaunt faces a chilling mirror of the order they profess to serve.

items: 4 {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}.
1 {@creature Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}.

entries: Their goal is not to kill but to capture—they believe the adventurers are fated sacrifices or useful tools for their cause. The priest's eyes glow with a fanatic's devotion as he gestures, commanding his acolytes. "Chosen offerings," he declares, his voice a low hiss, "you walk willingly into our master's grace!"

items: The acolytes and priest fight fiercely but with a reckless abandon. They prefer non-lethal strikes (such as the flats of their blades or blows to the head) to subdue the party, though their fanaticism may lead to lethal force if they are cornered. This combat will serve as a hard test of the party's skills.
After a few rounds, the priest may use a spell to try and disorient the party, attempting to give the acolytes an advantage.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: If the party is defeated, they will awaken bound and unconscious at the entrance to the ruins, starting Chapter 3 at a disadvantage. If the party wins, the priest is left critically wounded and can be interrogated.

items: With a successful {@dc 15} {@skill Persuasion} or {@skill Intimidation} check, the priest, in his dying breaths, reveals:
A clear path to the Ruin of Silver Light, a twisted stairway covered in thorny vines.
A dark hint that the cult seeks to 'awaken their chained master'— {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet.
A final, chilling warning: "You think you walk toward salvation... but you walk willingly into the maw of eternity."

entries: With the ambush resolved, the adventurers can now find the overgrown stairway that marks the temple entrance, where this chapter ends. The darkness of the forest gives way to the true corruption of the ruins.
Use the table bellow for player if they looting:

data.name: Chapter 3: The Ruin of Silver Light

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: This is the climax of the adventure, where the party faces the source of the city's corruption. This chapter is designed as a two-phase combat encounter, escalating from a standard battle against the cult leaders to a full-blown boss fight. The transition should be dramatic, triggered by the players' success in the first phase. The final intervention by the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra} serves as a narrative device to prevent a Total Party Kill, making the encounter cinematic and allowing the story to flow into the epilogue.

entries.name: The Temple Gate
entries: After navigating the corrupted forest, the adventurers arrive at what was once the grand entrance to the temple of the Silver Light. The gate stands as a grim silhouette against the stormy sky, its intricate carvings of Vaeil and his celestial Archives now defaced and covered in abyssal glyphs. The air here is cold and heavy with the scent of decay. A low, guttural chanting echoes from within the ruins, a foul perversion of the order's old prayers. The path leads to a shattered, overgrown stairway that descends into darkness.

entries.name: The High Priest's Stand
entries: As the adventurers descend into the main hall of the temple, the chanting stops. Five figures stand before a jagged rift in reality, their silver robes stained with blood and filth. In the center, the High Priest, a Drow Elf, turns to face them, his eyes glowing with black light. He is flanked by two robed Priests and three hooded Acolytes, who clutch their daggers with zealous fervor. The High Priest raises his hands, his voice echoing with a cruel mockery of Vaeil's blessing. "You have intruded on the most sacred of rituals," he hisses. "You are not a sacrifice... you are simply a feast!"

items: The encounter is with the following creatures:
1 {@creature High Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
2 {@creature Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
3 {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
The High Priest will prioritize using spells to weaken and control the party, while the acolytes attack recklessly to wear them down.
The goal of the cultists is to incapacitate the adventurers for sacrifice, but they will not hold back on lethal force if the party proves too resilient.

entries: The battle is a tense, desperate struggle. The moment the High Priest's hit points are reduced to 50% or less, or when half of his accompanying forces have been defeated, the ground trembles and the final phase of the battle begins.

entries.name: The Abyssal Maw
entries: The rift behind the High Priest tears open with a deafening screech of rending metal. The abyssal chanting swells into a roar as the true lord of these ruins emerges: {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}. A gargantuan, multi-limbed creature of nightmare, it is a fleshy, chitinous horror with an impossibly wide maw filled with rows of razor-sharp teeth. Its body seems to warp and pull at the space around it, its movements erratic and alien. It has been a long time since its master fed it so well, and it is hungry for more.

entries.name: The Light of Vaeil
entries: If the party is defeated or clearly losing the battle against the {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}, a blinding light erupts from the sky, a single, brilliant ray that shatters the temple's ceiling. This is the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}'s power, a desperate act to correct a timeline that has gone too far. The light strikes the Maw, scorching it and instantly incinerating any remaining cultists. The Maw's body convulses, and it is left with only 20% of its total hit points remaining. The air shimmers with temporal energy, and for a fleeting moment, the adventurers catch a glimpse of the beggar woman from the tavern, her eyes glowing with impossible power, before the scene resets.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: Whether by their own hand or by the grace of the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, the adventurers defeat the {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}. As the monstrosity's body dissolves, a final, guttural scream tears from the rift in reality. The archdemon manifests in his true, gargantuan form—an overwhelming being of pure abyss and despair. This is where the adventure's epilogue begins.
A {@item Fragment of the Archive|MTW-VS} is laying beside the High Priest and can be taken.

data.name: Epilogue

entries.name: The Boar Smile Tavern Revisited
entries: The rain pours heavily outside as thunder rattles the windows of the Boar Smile Tavern. Every table is full, leaving you no choice but to share one with strangers. The warmth of the hearth fills the room, carrying the sound of laughter and song.

A group of Silver Light acolytes sit near the bar, their silver-embroidered robes bright in the firelight. They raise cups with locals, blessing farmers and cradling newborns offered into their arms. A villager smiles at you warmly and whispers:
The Silver Light keeps us safe. {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s blessings shine upon Dewanginokori once more.
A figure in hooded white robe approaches the bar you guys were sitting, after ordering a mead from Demolias they turn at you and put off the hood of their robe.
A woman with golden hair, her eyes is shining from the light reflection with a silver hue. She wave and greeted you
'Hello, my name is {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}'
And there's where our adventure would end.

Though the adventurers recall the horrors faced within the Silver Forest, none around them seem to bear such memories. Time has been rewritten by {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, fragment of Vaeil, restoring Dewanginokori to its golden age.

The loop closes where it began—the Boar Smile Tavern, the rain, the strangers at a crowded table—but now the weight of destiny hangs heavy. For the Archive remains threatened, and this was but the first page of a greater tale.

data.name: Vaeil
data.symbol: A serene, all-seeing eye within a perfect clock, surrounded by the Ouroboros.
entries: {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is the benevolent deity who brought order from primordial chaos and established the flow of time. He is the guardian of the timeline, ensuring that the grand design of the cosmos unfolds as it should.

While {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is often seen as a distant and impassive force, his influence is felt in the cycles of the seasons, the turning of the stars, and the natural progression of life and death. His followers, such as the {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}, strive to maintain order, preserve knowledge, and protect the world from the disruptive influence of chaotic forces.

{@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}'s power is not one of direct intervention, but of subtle guidance and correction. He acts through his devoted followers to restore balance and mend the tears in the fabric of reality caused by beings like {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}. His greatest triumph was the ending of the {@adventure War of Sundering|MTW|war-of-sundering}, which he accomplished by resetting time, an act that fractured a part of his soul, creating the entity known as {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}.

In her humanoid form, she appears as a striking but unassuming human woman with silver-streaked hair and eyes that occasionally flicker with an inner light. This form is her preferred way to interact with mortals, as it helps her remain inconspicuous while still maintaining an air of otherworldly grace.

entries: {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the primordial chaos that exists outside of time. It is not a being of flesh and blood but a malevolent force that seeks to unravel the orderly fabric of the multiverse, which was woven by {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}.

Unlike other demons who seek power or conquest, {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}'s sole purpose is the ultimate unmaking of all things, returning them to the chaotic void from which it came. Its influence is insidious, working through whispers and subversion rather than brute force.

{@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the master of lies, twisting the faith of mortals, and turning order against itself. The {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS} in your adventure secretly worships {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}, seeing its chaotic nature as true freedom from the gods' strictures. Adult white dragons claim large territories and are often the mightiest predators in those lands. While some lurk in their lairs for months, others regularly soar over their domains. When they spot something moving on the ice, they might swoop down to feed or extort food and offerings from sapient creatures.

entries.name: White Dragons
entries: {@i Dragons of Cold and Cruelty}

Among the most primal chromatic dragons, white dragons prioritize survival over all. Life is harsh and uncertain in the arctic expanses, glacial heights, and frozen seas where these dragons dwell. White dragons fiercely protect their territories, scouring the frigid regions for food and evidence of trespassers. Most white dragons ignore the plots of smaller creatures and other dragons, concerning themselves only with their own survival.

White dragons create lairs to defend themselves from other deadly arctic creatures and from dangerous natural conditions. Within these shelters, white dragons hoard testaments to their superiority, such as monstrous skulls, the gear of defeated rivals, and curiosities that capture their interest. To protect such treasure, white dragons coax ice to form over their hoards or sink their wealth in frigid pools. For white dragons, each piece of treasure embodies a victory—the details of which inflate as these dragons age.

entries.name: White Dragon Lairs
entries: White dragons brood in bitterly cold lairs clawed from stone and ice.
The region containing an adult or ancient white dragon's lair is affected by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Frigid Cold
entries: The area within 1 mile of the lair is an area of {@hazard extreme cold|XDMG}. Any water in that area is {@hazard frigid water|XDMG}. See the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for rules on extreme cold and frigid water.

items.name: Glacial Gloom
entries: The area within 1 mile of the lair is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB} by chilly fog. Whenever a creature other than the dragon or one of its allies finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in that area, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} reduced by 10 feet for 1 hour.
If the dragon dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

entries: Vaelithra can use her action to polymorph into a Medium humanoid she has seen, or back into her true form. Her statistics, other than her size, are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.

In her humanoid form, she appears as a striking but unassuming human woman with silver-streaked hair and eyes that occasionally flicker with an inner light. This form is her preferred way to interact with mortals, as it helps her remain inconspicuous while still maintaining an air of otherworldly grace.
